@guozhangwang I was under the impression you suggested throwing the exception at a higher level in the comments of KAFKA-5006. Perhaps I misunderstood? The idea here is to throw the exception at the appropriate level, with the appropriate high level message at that layer. Instead of at the lower level RecordCollector.

Removing the `Running->NotRunning` in `KafkaStreams` is not easy/possible. To recap, ideally for a clean shutdown we have `Running->PendingShutdown->NotRunning.`

However:

- in the case when an exception happens in a thread (assume just 1 thread in total) AND the unhandled exception handler does NOT call `streams.close()` then all the threads are `DEAD` and the instance transitions from `Running->NotRunning`. There is `PENDING_SHUTDOWN` in the middle since no one called `close()`.

This could be classified as a bug in our logic. If all streams threads are DEAD, maybe our own code should call close()? What do you think? cc @mjsax @dguy @guozhangwang

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/5796/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

About `ProducerFenced` -- it will be propagated to `StreamThread` and should be caught there. If  this happens, we close the task as zombie and swallow, ie, the thread does not die and we keep processing.

In contrast, all other exceptions will kill the thread and thus it makes sense to log "will be propagated" IMHO.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/5795/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

> then all the threads are DEAD and the instance transitions from Running->NotRunning

> Why this will happen? Currently in the code even if all threads dies the instance will not automatically shut itself down right?

Yes indeed. I'm just wondering what do you want the state to be when all threads are dead. I'd argue it should be `NOT_RUNNING` right? When all threads are DEAD, I set the state of the instance to `NOT_RUNNING`. Is that bad? In addition, I'm wondering if the code should actually go ahead and call close() if all threads are dead.
